001package imagingbook.lib.filter;
002
003import ij.process.ImageProcessor;
004import imagingbook.lib.filter.examples.ExampleFilterScalar;
005import imagingbook.lib.filter.examples.FilterShowProgressExample;
006import imagingbook.lib.filter.examples.ExampleFilterVector;
007import imagingbook.lib.image.access.GridIndexer2D;
008import imagingbook.lib.image.access.OutOfBoundsStrategy;
009import imagingbook.lib.image.data.PixelPack;
010import imagingbook.lib.image.data.PixelPack.PixelSlice;
011import imagingbook.lib.util.progress.ProgressMonitor;
012import imagingbook.lib.util.progress.ProgressReporter;
013import imagingbook.lib.util.progress.ij.ProgressBarMonitor;
014
015/**
016 * <p>This is the (abstract) root class of the generic filter hierarchy.
017 * Generic filters are designed to work with all types of
018 * ImageJ images, i.e., sub-classes of {@link ImageProcessor}.
019 * Filters implemented with this framework use a set of unified
020 * image data structures, all based on {@code float} values
021 * (see {@link PixelPack} and {@link PixelSlice}).
022 * Input images are transparently copied from and back to these
023 * float data, thus authors of new filters do not need to concern themselves
024 * with the original pixel data types.
025 * Behind the scenes, classes {@link GridIndexer2D} and {@link OutOfBoundsStrategy} are relevant for
026 * pixel indexing and out-of-boundary coordinates handling.
027 * </p>
028 * <p>
029 * Generic filters support multiple passes, the associated control 
030 * structures are implemented by this class {@link GenericFilter}.
031 * Most filters only require a single pass.
032 * If more passes are required, the concrete (terminal) filter class
033 * should override the method {@link #passesRequired()} to return the 
034 * required number, which may change dynamically during the execution 
035 * of the filter (e.g., to reach convergence of some sort).
036 * Sub-classes provide definitions for scalar filters, i.e., filters
037 * that operate independently on the different components of color images
038 * (e.g., see {@link GenericFilterScalar}),
039 * as opposed to vector vector filters that deal with color datea as
040 * vectors (e.g., see {@link GenericFilterVector}).
041 * In addition, both types provide sub-classes for X/Y-separable versions
042 * (see {@link GenericFilterScalarSeparable} and {@link GenericFilterVectorSeparable}).
043 * </p>
044 * <p>
045 * In the simplest (though frequent) case a concrete filter class only needs 
046 * to implement a single method to specify the work to be done for calculating the
047 * value of a single image pixel (e.g., see 
048 * {@link GenericFilterVector#doPixel(PixelPack, int, int)} and
049 * {@link GenericFilterScalar#doPixel(PixelSlice, int, int)}).
050 * See {@link ExampleFilterScalar} and {@link ExampleFilterVector} for examples.
051 * </p>
052 * <p>
053 * To <strong>apply</strong> as filter to a given image, the key method is 
054 * {@link #applyTo(ImageProcessor)} (or {@link #applyTo(PixelPack)} if
055 * the pixel data are already available as a {@link PixelPack}).
056 * All filters operate destructively, i.e., by modifying the supplied image.
057 * </p>
058 * <p>
059 * {@link GenericFilter}s support asynchronous <strong>progress reporting</strong> based on the
060 * {@link ProgressMonitor} framework. Here is a usage example (from one of the sample plugins):</p>
061 * <pre>
062 * ImageProcessor ip = ... // any image
063 * ...
064 * GenericFilter filter = new TschumperleDericheFilter();
065 * try (ProgressMonitor m = new ProgressBarMonitor(filter)) {
066 *     filter.applyTo(ip);
067 * }</pre>
068 * <p>
069 * During execution of the filter, the {@link ProgressBarMonitor} instance queries the filter
070 * periodically (in a separate thread) for its progress status and updates ImageJ's progress
071 * bar.
072 * </p>
073 * 
074 * @author WB
075 * @version 2012/01/12
076 */
077public abstract class GenericFilter implements ProgressReporter {
078        
079        private class AbortFilterException extends RuntimeException {
080                private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;
081        }
082        
083        private PixelPack source = null;
084        private PixelPack target = null;
085        private int pass = -1;
086        
087        public GenericFilter() {
088        }
089        
090        // --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
091
092        /**
093         * Returns the current filter pass number, starting with 0.
094         * @return the filter pass number
095         */
096        protected int getPass() {
097                return pass;
098        }
099        
100        /**
101         * Returns the width of the currently processed image.
102         * @return the width of the image
103         */
104        protected int getWidth() {
105                if (source == null) {
106                        throw new IllegalStateException("width is unknown unless filter is invoked");
107                }
108                return source.getWidth();
109        }
110        
111        /**
112         * Returns the height of the currently processed image.
113         * @return the height of the image
114         */
115        protected int getHeight() {
116                if (source == null) {
117                        throw new IllegalStateException("height is unknown unless filter is invoked");
118                }
119                return source.getHeight();
120        }
121        
122        /**
123         * Returns the depth (number of components) of the currently processed image.
124         * @return the depth of the image
125         */
126        protected int getDepth() {
127                if (source == null) {
128                        throw new IllegalStateException("depth is unknown unless filter is invoked");
129                }
130                return source.getDepth();
131        }
132        
133        // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
134        
135        /**
136         * Applies this filter to the given {@link PixelPack} instance, which is modified.
137         * @param source the image to be filtered
138         */
139        public void applyTo(PixelPack source) {
140                this.source = source;
141                this.target = new PixelPack(source);    // empty copy of same dimensions as source
142                runFilter(source, target);
143        }
144        
145        private void runFilter(PixelPack source, PixelPack target) {    // do we always want to copy back??
146                initFilter(source, target);
147                pass = 0;
148                try {
149                        while (pass < passesRequired()) {       // TODO: check return value of passesRequired()!
150                                //IJ.log("****** starting pass " + pass);
151                                initPass(source, target);
152                                runPass(source, target);
153                                target.copyTo(this.source); // copy target back to sources
154                                pass++;
155                        }
156                } catch (AbortFilterException e) {};
157                // the filter's result is to be found in 'source'
158                closeFilter();
159                this.source = null;
160                this.target = null;
161        }
162        
163        // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
164        
165        /**
166         * Applies this filter to the given {@link ImageProcessor}, which is modified.
167         * {@link PixelPack#DefaultOutOfBoundsStrategy} is used to handle out-of-bounds coordinates.
168         * @param ip the image to be filtered
169         */
170        public void applyTo(ImageProcessor ip) {
171                applyTo(ip, PixelPack.DefaultOutOfBoundsStrategy);
172        }
173        
174        /**
175         * Applies this filter to the given {@link ImageProcessor}, which is modified;
176         * the specified {@link OutOfBoundsStrategy} is used to handle out-of-bounds coordinates.
177         * @param ip the image to be filtered
178         * @param obs the out-of-bounds strategy to be used
179         */
180        public void applyTo(ImageProcessor ip, OutOfBoundsStrategy obs) {
181                PixelPack pp = new PixelPack(ip, obs);
182                applyTo(pp);
183                pp.copyToImageProcessor(ip);    // copy data back to ip
184        }
185        
186        // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
187        
188        // called once before the filter operations starts.
189        // 
190        // that depend on the image size
191        /**
192         * This method is called once at the start of the filter execution.
193         * It does nothing by default.
194         * Concrete filter classes should override this method, 
195         * e.g., for setting up temporary data structures.
196         * 
197         * @param source the image source data
198         * @param target the image target data
199         */
200        protected void initFilter(PixelPack source, PixelPack target) {
201                // does nothing by default
202        }
203        
204        /**
205         * This method is called once at the start of each filter pass.
206         * It does nothing by default.
207         * Concrete filter classes should override this method if needed.
208         * @param source the image source data
209         * @param target the image target data
210         */
211        protected void initPass(PixelPack source, PixelPack target) {
212                // does nothing by default
213        }
214        
215        // concrete sub-classes should override to purge 
216        // specific data structures if needed
217        /**
218         * This method is called once when the filter terminates.
219         * It does nothing by default.
220         * Concrete filter classes should override this method if needed.
221         */
222        protected void closeFilter() {
223        }
224        
225        // limits the necessary number of passes, which may not be known at initialization.
226        // multi-pass filters must override this method.
227        /**
228         * Returns the necessary number of passes, which may change during execution 
229         * of the filter. The value 1 is returned by default.
230         * Multi-pass filters must override this method.
231         * The filter terminates as soon as the requested number of passes is reached.
232         * This this method can be used to terminate filter execution once some desired
233         * state has been reached (e.g., convergence).
234         * See also {@link #getPass()}.
235         * 
236         * @return the required number of filter passes
237         */
238        protected int passesRequired() {
239                return 1;       // do exactly 1 pass
240        }
241        
242        /**
243         * This method can be called to abort the filter execution prematurely,
244         * e.g. for debugging.
245         */
246        protected final void abort() {
247                throw new AbortFilterException();
248        }
249
250        /**
251         * This method performs one pass of the filter, it must be implemented by a sub-class.
252         * There is usually no need for a custom filter class to override this method.
253         * 
254         * @param source the image source data
255         * @param target the image target data
256         */
257        protected abstract void runPass(PixelPack source, PixelPack target);
258        
259        // progress reporting ----------------------------------------------------------------
260
261        @Override
262        public final double getProgress() {
263                double fp = reportProgress();
264                return this.reportProgress(fp);
265        }
266        
267        // 
268        /**
269         * This method is called asynchonously and may be overridden by the terminal filter class 
270         * if it does extensive work that should be monitored. 
271         * In this case the method must return a value between 0 and 1, reflecting the degree of completion
272         * (only of the final class's subtask) at the time of invocation.
273         * Normally this is not necessary, since the intermediate classes
274         * return their own progress state (for the less granular tasks) anyways.
275         * The default implementations returns 0 (progress).
276         * See {@link FilterShowProgressExample} for an example.
277         * @return the degree of completion (0,...,1)
278         */
279        protected double reportProgress() {
280                return 0;
281        }
282        
283        /** This method is used for internal progress reporting through the class hierarchy. It should
284         * not be overridden or modified.
285         * 
286         * @param subProgress the current progress reported by the immediate sub-task (0,...,1)
287         * @return the cumulative progress (0,...,1)
288         */
289        protected double reportProgress(double subProgress) {
290                int pass = Math.max(getPass(), 0);      // getPass() returns -1 if loop is not started 
291                double localProgress = (pass + subProgress) / passesRequired();
292                return localProgress; // this is the final value returned to the monitor
293        }
294}
